title: If someone had never really heard rock, would the Rolling Stones and U2 be the best to introduce a normal consumer to? - Quora

response.answer_text: U2 absolutely not. And I say that as a someone who was a legitimate fan once, and still enjoys some of their material today. Instrumentally, their playing is often atypical of what many would regard as fairly standard rock music. Whether by design or because of limitations. Whether you love or hate Bono’s lyrics, he has a distinctive way with words, and covers topics that aren’t especially usual of rock music (more so in their earlier material), or at least are examined from a somewhat different perspective. Rolling Stones — maybe. Kinda sorta. There is no argument they’re historically relevant, and embody the rock & roll spirit as well or better than most. I think part of my reluctance with them, is Jagger’s voice. I’m not a great fan of his singing — he suffers from MPM (Mashed Potato Mouth) syndrome to my ears. Albeit I’d never want anyone else to front the Stones, ever (aside from the odd song sung by Keith - and he too has a less than an aesthetically soaring voice — much less); that is the voice of the Rolling Stones, all imperfections notwithstanding. But god forbid anyone would hear his voice and think ‘Oh, so that’s what a fairly typical rock vocalist sounds like!’ I’d run with the Beatles and Led Zeppelin, personally. The former to convey that rock music can run the gamut from very basic and straightforward to strikingly avant-garde. And the latter to demonstrate that it can encompass light electric and delicate acoustic sounds, as well as pounding, punishing riffs and banshee keening, sometimes even in the same song.

Tough question to answer, because you have a wide range of artists to choose from (unless we’re just talking about hard rock). For example, you probably need to introduce them to first Elvis, Chuck Berry, Little Richard and Buddy Holly (at least) from the birth of rock. You simply can’t ignore The Beatles, who (IMHO) took basic rock and altered it in so many different ways. Most influential and important band ever, again in my opinion. They have to be included. The Stones are arguably the original mold for what a typical rock band looks and acts like today, so they have to be included. The Who were the first or one of the first practitioners of hard rock / punk rock, so they need to be on the list. Zeppelin was a blues band that enhanced hard rock. They weren’t the first, but they were important for their time. U2 can be included. I find them a closer cousin to The Beatles (you could almost take any track from Achtung Baby and drop it into the middle of The White Album, and it would fit). I personally don’t think they’re as influential as some or all of the bands listed above, but that can at least be argued. There you go. My answer, based soley on my subjective opinion…
